title: 106_hr902
content: The "Gun Show Accountability Act" may be cited as the short title of this Act. The findings section is included in the Act. Congress finds that more than 4,400 traditional gun shows are held annually across the United States, attracting thousands of attendees and firearms sellers. These events play a significant role in the national firearms market and impact interstate commerce. Gun shows, flea markets, and other organized events provide a centralized location for buying and selling firearms without background checks, enabling criminals to obtain untraceable guns for later criminal activities. Gun shows, flea markets, and other organized events facilitate the interstate transportation of firearms, contributing to the national issue of gun violence. Firearms obtained at these events have been illegally transferred across state lines and used in various crimes. Congress has the authority to regulate this under the interstate commerce clause and other constitutional provisions. The Act aims to prevent criminals and prohibited persons from acquiring firearms at gun shows, flea markets, and organized events to comply with the Constitution and regulate interstate firearm transportation. Extension of Brady background checks to gun shows. The definitions of "Gun Show," "Gun Show Promoter," and "Gun Show Vendor" are provided in an amendment to Section 921(a) of title 18, United States Code. The text discusses the regulation of firearms transfers at gun shows, requiring gun show promoters to register with the Secretary and pay a registration fee. Gun show promoters must also fulfill certain responsibilities to operate a gun show legally. Gun show promoters must notify the Secretary of the gun show details, submit a list of vendors, verify vendor identities, and fulfill other requirements before the gun show begins. Gun show vendors must sign a ledger with identifying information and a notice of their obligations before the show, notify attendees of the requirements, submit required documents to the Secretary after the show, and maintain records at the promoter's place of business as per regulations. Gun show vendors must comply with regulations set by the Secretary for firearm transactions at gun shows, including the requirement for non-licensed individuals to transfer firearms through licensed importers, manufacturers, or dealers. Criminal background checks must be conducted before transferring a firearm to a non-licensed individual. Transfer of firearms at gun shows must be done through licensed importers, manufacturers, or dealers to comply with regulations. Non-licensed individuals cannot receive firearms from other non-licensed individuals at gun shows unless the transfer is made through a licensed entity. Licensed individuals must go through a licensed importer, manufacturer, or dealer for firearm transfers at gun shows to comply with regulations. They cannot receive firearms from non-licensed individuals unless the transfer is made through a licensed entity. Licensed individuals must comply with regulations by going through a licensed importer, manufacturer, or dealer for firearm transfers at gun shows. They must enter required information into a record, use a specified form, and comply with section 922(t) when assisting non-licensed individuals with firearm transfers. Licensed individuals must comply with regulations by using licensed importers, manufacturers, or dealers for firearm transfers at gun shows. They must notify non-licensed transferors and transferees of compliance with section 922(t) and submit a transfer report to the Secretary within 10 days. Licensed individuals must prepare a report of multiple transfers if they assist in transferring two or more pistols or revolvers to the same non-licensed person within a specified time frame. The report must be submitted to the Secretary on a specified form by the close of business on the transfer date. Licensed individuals must submit a report of firearm transfers at gun shows to the Secretary within 10 days of the transfer date. The report must be forwarded to the specified office and State law enforcement agency, and a record of the transfer must be retained as part of the permanent business records. The Secretary requires a report of firearm transfers at gun shows within 10 days, following specific guidelines and penalties for violations. The penalties for violating firearm transfer regulations at gun shows include fines and imprisonment for up to 5 years for repeat offenders. Additionally, the Secretary may impose further penalties on those who knowingly violate the regulations. The penalties for violating firearm transfer regulations at gun shows include fines, imprisonment for up to 5 years for repeat offenders, suspension or revocation of registration, and a civil fine of up to $10,000. Technical and conforming amendments are made to Chapter 44 of title 18, United States Code. The amendment allows the Secretary to inspect gun show promoters' businesses and show locations without a warrant to ensure compliance with firearm regulations. Increased penalties are imposed for serious recordkeeping violations. Increased penalties for serious recordkeeping violations by licensees include fines, imprisonment up to 5 years for certain offenses under section 922(b), and fines, imprisonment for not more than 1 year, or both for other violations. Increased penalties for violations of criminal background check requirements under section 922(t) include fines, imprisonment up to 5 years, or both. Certain elements of the offense under section 922(t)(5) are eliminated. The section and its amendments will take effect 180 days after the enactment of the Act.
